title: The Narrative Edge: A Leadership Impact Assessment
description: Stop presenting. Start influencing. This assessment identifies the specific storytelling gaps that are keeping your ideas from gaining the traction they deserve.

elements.name: opening
elements.title: 1. You're starting a high-stakes presentation. What's your first move?

choices.text: Walk through the agenda to manage expectations.
Start with a joke or a light-hearted icebreaker.
Share a 'Moment of Crisis' or a surprising insight that challenges the status quo.

elements.name: conflict
elements.title: 2. A project failed. How do you present this to the Board?

choices.text: Focus on the external factors and market conditions that caused it.
Identify the specific 'Turning Point' where a decision failed and what we learned.
Gloss over it quickly to get to the 'positive' forward-looking KPIs.

elements.name: hero
elements.title: 3. Who is the central character (the hero) of your typical sales pitch or strategy deck?

choices.text: Our team—highlighting our expertise and track record.
The client/customer—navigating a world of change.
The product or data—the facts should speak for themselves.

elements.name: data
elements.title: 4. How do you handle complex data on a slide?

choices.text: Show the full spreadsheet/chart so the audience can see the 'full picture'.
Simplify the visual to highlight a single, undeniable 'headline' insight.
Keep the data as is, but talk over it with a completely different story.

elements.name: brevity
elements.title: 5. You are told your 20-minute slot has been cut to 5 minutes. What do you do?

choices.text: Talk faster to cover all the slides.
Skip to the final 'Conclusion' and 'Thank You' slides.
Ditch the deck and tell one story that embodies the main goal.

elements.name: resistance
elements.title: 6. A senior leader interrupts your story with a cynical question. How do you react?

choices.text: Provide more data immediately to prove them wrong.
Acknowledge the validity of their doubt and integrate it into the story.
Politely ask to hold all questions until the end.

elements.name: emotion
elements.title: 7. How much 'emotion' or personal anecdote belongs in a technical business case?

choices.text: None. Business decisions must be purely rational.
Significant. People decide on emotion and justify with logic.
A little, but only if it's a 'safe' or common corporate example.

elements.name: call_to_action
elements.title: 8. How do you usually end a presentation?

choices.text: A slide that says 'Questions?'
A summary of the points already discussed.
A 'Call to Adventure'—a clear, vivid description of the next step.

elements.name: analogies
elements.title: 9. When explaining a complex new technology, what is your go-to method?

choices.text: Using the correct technical terminology to ensure precision.
Using an analogy (e.g., 'It’s like an Uber for X').
Showing a diagram of the architecture.

elements.name: preparation
elements.title: 10. How do you rehearse for a presentation?

choices.text: Reading through my speaker notes several times.
Focusing on the transitions between slides.
Recording myself to check for 'filler words' and emotional resonance.

completedHtml:
Your Narrative DNA: {archetype}

Total Mastery Score: {totalScore} / 50

Core Shortcomings Identified:

    {improvementList}

Your Strategic Growth Goal:

{strategicGoal}

calculatedValues.name: archetype
calculatedValues.expression: iif({totalScore} <= 20, 'The Informational Expert', iif({totalScore} <= 35, 'The Confident Communicator', 'The Strategic Catalyst'))

calculatedValues.name: improvementList
calculatedValues.expression:
iif({totalScore} <= 20, '
  • Over-reliance on data at the expense of meaning.
  • Lack of empathy-based audience mapping.
  • Weak narrative hooks (starting with agendas).
    • ', iif({totalScore} <= 35, '
  • Safe storytelling (avoiding the necessary tension).
  • Presenter-centric focus (making yourself the hero).
  • Ineffective handling of skeptical stakeholders.
    • ', '
  • Over-polishing (losing raw authenticity).
  • Need for more concise, high-impact metaphors.
  • Mentoring others to build a culture of storytelling.
    • '))

calculatedValues.name: strategicGoal
calculatedValues.expression: iif({totalScore} <= 20, 'Goal: Shift from being a source of information to a source of inspiration by finding the human stake in every data point.', iif({totalScore} <= 35, 'Goal: Move from being a comfortable speaker to a courageous storyteller who uses tension to drive change.', 'Goal: Mastery of executive presence—using silence, nuance, and strategic narratives to lead through uncertainty.'))
